conclusion: Analyze the motion of blocks P and Q before and after the first collision using conservation of momentum and mechanical energy.
Block P is moving up the incline with initial velocity v0; Block Q is at rest.
In an elastic collision, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.
For block P, the only force acting is the component of the gravitational force down the incline, which is m g sin θ.

For block Q, the forces are the component of the gravitational force down the incline (4 m g sin θ), the normal force perpendicular to the incline, and the frictional force μ N = tan θ ⋅ 4 m g cos θ = 4 m g sin θ.
Conservation of momentum: m v0 = m vP1 + 4m vQ1, simplifying to v0 = vP1 + 4 vQ1.
Conservation of kinetic energy: 1/2 m v0^2 = 1/2 m vP1^2 + 1/2 ⋅ 4m vQ1^2, simplifying to v0^2 = vP1^2 + 4 vQ1^2.
Solve the system of equations: vP1 = v0 - 4 vQ1, substitute into kinetic energy equation.
Expand and simplify: v0^2 = v0^2 - 8 v0 vQ1 + 16 vQ1^2 + 4 vQ1^2, leading to 0 = -8 v0 vQ1 + 20 vQ1^2.
Solve for vQ1: 8 v0 vQ1 = 20 vQ1^2, leading to vQ1 = 2 v0/5.
Substitute vQ1 back into momentum equation: vP1 = v0 - 4 (2 v0/5) = v0 - 8 v0/5 = -3 v0/5.
Final velocities: vP1 = -3 v0/5, vQ1 = 2 v0/5.
The magnitudes of the velocities are |vP1| = 3 v0/5, |vQ1| = 2 v0/5.
The magnitudes of the velocities of P and Q immediately after the first collision are 3 v0/5 and 2 v0/5, respectively.
